sentence: C onsumer staple dividend leaders likeKimberly-Clark ( KMB ) andProcter & Gamble ( PG ) have come under selling pressure after both reported earnings recently and talked about the negative effects of the strong dollar on their business.
But one consumer staple name,Clorox ( CLX ), has curiously withstood the selling so far even though it's susceptible to the strong dollar, too.
Investors will get detailed color on the company's fiscal second-quarter results when Clorox reports Wednesday before the open.
The Thomson Reuters consensus estimate calls for profit of 90 cents a share, up 2% from a year ago, with sales down 2% to $1.3 billion.
Shares rallied after the company reported first-quarter earnings in late October.
Quarterly profit rose 5% from a year ago.
Excluding currency fluctuations, sales would have been up 3%.
The company's Cleaning segment, which includes brands like Clorox, Pine-Sol and Liquid-Plumr, accounted for 32% of sales in fiscal 2014.
Brands in its Household segment included Glad bags, wraps and containers, Kingsford charcoal and Fresh Step cat litter.

This segment accounted for 31% of sales in 2014.

International sales made up 20% of sales in 2014.
Clorox is no stranger to takeover chatter.
In 2011, the company rejected a $10.2 billion offer from Carl Icahn.
Shares surged 7% on Sept. 22 on more takeover chatter.
The same day, the company announced plans to exit Venezuela because of high inflation and government-mandated price freezes.
As a result, the company was forced to sell products at a loss.
Clorox raised its quarterly dividend to 74 cents a share in May.
